funcs.name: memcache_connect
funcs.desc: Memcache::connect() establishes a connection to the memcached server. The connection, which was opened using Memcache::connect() will be automatically closed at the end of script execution. Also you can close it with Memcache::close(). Also you can use memcache_connect() function.

return.desc: Returns TRUE on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: host
args.desc: Point to the host where memcached is listening for connections. This parameter may also specify other transports like unix:///path/to/memcached.sock to use UNIX domain sockets, in this case port must also be set to 0.

args.name: port
args.desc: Point to the port where memcached is listening for connections. Set this parameter to 0 when using UNIX domain sockets.

args.name: timeout
args.desc: Value in seconds which will be used for connecting to the daemon. Think twice before changing the default value of 1 second - you can lose all the advantages of caching if your connection is too slow.

funcs.name: memcache_pconnect
funcs.desc: Memcache::pconnect() is similar to Memcache::connect() with the difference, that the connection it establishes is persistent. This connection is not closed after the end of script execution and by Memcache::close() function. Also you can use memcache_pconnect() function.

return.desc: Returns TRUE on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: host
args.desc: Point to the host where memcached is listening for connections. This parameter may also specify other transports like unix:///path/to/memcached.sock to use UNIX domain sockets, in this case port must also be set to 0.

args.name: port
args.desc: Point to the port where memcached is listening for connections. Set this parameter to 0 when using UNIX domain sockets.

args.name: timeout
args.desc: Value in seconds which will be used for connecting to the daemon. Think twice before changing the default value of 1 second - you can lose all the advantages of caching if your connection is too slow.

funcs.name: memcache_add
funcs.desc: Memcache::add() stores variable var with key only if such key doesn't exist at the server yet. Also you can use memcache_add() function.

return.desc: Returns TRUE on success or FALSE on failure. Returns FALSE if such key already exist. For the rest Memcache::add() behaves similarly to Memcache::set().

args.name: memcache
args.desc: The key that will be associated with the item.

args.name: key
args.desc: The variable to store. Strings and integers are stored as is, other types are stored serialized.

args.name: var
args.desc: Use MEMCACHE_COMPRESSED to store the item compressed (uses zlib).

args.name: flag
args.desc: Expiration time of the item. If it's equal to zero, the item will never expire. You can also use Unix timestamp or a number of seconds starting from current time, but in the latter case the number of seconds may not exceed 2592000 (30 days).

funcs.name: memcache_set
funcs.desc:
Memcache::set() stores an item var with key on the memcached server. Parameter expire is expiration time in seconds. If it's 0, the item never expires (but memcached server doesn't guarantee this item to be stored all the time, it could be deleted from the cache to make place for other items). You can use MEMCACHE_COMPRESSED constant as flag value if you want to use on-the-fly compression (uses zlib).

Remember that resource variables (i.e. file and connection descriptors) cannot be stored in the cache, because they cannot be adequately represented in serialized state. Also you can use memcache_set() function.

return.desc: Returns TRUE on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: memcache
args.desc: The key that will be associated with the item.

args.name: key
args.desc: The variable to store. Strings and integers are stored as is, other types are stored serialized.

args.name: var
args.desc: Use MEMCACHE_COMPRESSED to store the item compressed (uses zlib).

args.name: flag
args.desc: Expiration time of the item. If it's equal to zero, the item will never expire. You can also use Unix timestamp or a number of seconds starting from current time, but in the latter case the number of seconds may not exceed 2592000 (30 days).

funcs.name: memcache_replace
funcs.desc: Memcache::replace() should be used to replace value of existing item with key. In case if item with such key doesn't exists, Memcache::replace() returns FALSE. For the rest Memcache::replace() behaves similarly to Memcache::set(). Also you can use memcache_replace() function.

return.desc: Returns TRUE on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: memcache
args.desc: The key that will be associated with the item.

args.name: key
args.desc: The variable to store. Strings and integers are stored as is, other types are stored serialized.

args.name: var
args.desc: Use MEMCACHE_COMPRESSED to store the item compressed (uses zlib).

args.name: flag
args.desc: Expiration time of the item. If it's equal to zero, the item will never expire. You can also use Unix timestamp or a number of seconds starting from current time, but in the latter case the number of seconds may not exceed 2592000 (30 days).

funcs.name: memcache_get
funcs.desc:
Memcache::get() returns previously stored data if an item with such key exists on the server at this moment.

You can pass array of keys to Memcache::get() to get array of values. The result array will contain only found key-value pairs.

return.desc: Returns the string associated with the key or FALSE on failure or if such key was not found.

args.name: memcache
args.desc: The key or array of keys to fetch.

args.name: key
args.desc: If present, flags fetched along with the values will be written to this parameter. These flags are the same as the ones given to for example Memcache::set(). The lowest byte of the int is reserved for pecl/memcache internal usage (e.g. to indicate compression and serialization status).

funcs.name: memcache_delete
funcs.desc: Memcache::delete() deletes item with the key. If parameter timeout is specified, the item will expire after timeout seconds. Also you can use memcache_delete() function.

return.desc: Returns TRUE on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: memcache
args.desc: The key associated with the item to delete.

args.name: key
args.desc: Execution time of the item. If it's equal to zero, the item will be deleted right away whereas if you set it to 30, the item will be deleted in 30 seconds.

funcs.name: memcache_increment
funcs.desc:
Memcache::increment() increments value of an item by the specified value. If item specified by key was not numeric and cannot be converted to a number, it will change its value to value. Memcache::increment() does not create an item if it doesn't already exist.

Do not use Memcache::increment() with items that have been stored compressed because subsequent calls to Memcache::get() will fail. Also you can use memcache_increment() function.

return.desc: Returns new items value on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: memcache
args.desc: Key of the item to increment.

args.name: key
args.desc: Increment the item by value.

funcs.name: memcache_decrement
funcs.desc:
Memcache::decrement() decrements value of the item by value. Similarly to Memcache::increment(), current value of the item is being converted to numerical and after that value is substracted.

New item's value will not be less than zero.

Do not use Memcache::decrement() with item, which was stored compressed, because consequent call to Memcache::get() will fail. Memcache::decrement() does not create an item if it didn't exist. Also you can use memcache_decrement() function.

return.desc: Returns item's new value on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: memcache
args.desc: Key of the item do decrement.

args.name: key
args.desc: Decrement the item by value.

funcs.name: memcache_close
funcs.desc: Memcache::close() closes connection to memcached server. This function doesn't close persistent connections, which are closed only during web-server shutdown/restart. Also you can use memcache_close() function.

return.desc: Returns TRUE on success or FALSE on failure.

funcs.name: memcache_flush
funcs.desc: Memcache::flush() immediately invalidates all existing items. Memcache::flush() doesn't actually free any resources, it only marks all the items as expired, so occupied memory will be overwritten by new items. Also you can use memcache_flush() function.

return.desc: Returns TRUE on success or FALSE on failure.

classes.name: Memcache
classes.desc: Represents a connection to a set of memcache servers.

funcs.name: connect
funcs.desc: Memcache::connect() establishes a connection to the memcached server. The connection, which was opened using Memcache::connect() will be automatically closed at the end of script execution. Also you can close it with Memcache::close(). Also you can use memcache_connect() function.

return.desc: Returns TRUE on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: host
args.desc: Point to the host where memcached is listening for connections. This parameter may also specify other transports like unix:///path/to/memcached.sock to use UNIX domain sockets, in this case port must also be set to 0.

args.name: port
args.desc: Point to the port where memcached is listening for connections. Set this parameter to 0 when using UNIX domain sockets.

args.name: timeout
args.desc: Value in seconds which will be used for connecting to the daemon. Think twice before changing the default value of 1 second - you can lose all the advantages of caching if your connection is too slow.

funcs.name: pconnect
funcs.desc: Memcache::pconnect() is similar to Memcache::connect() with the difference, that the connection it establishes is persistent. This connection is not closed after the end of script execution and by Memcache::close() function. Also you can use memcache_pconnect() function.

return.desc: Returns TRUE on success or FALSE on failure.

args.desc: Value in seconds which will be used for connecting to the daemon. Think twice before changing the default value of 1 second - you can lose all the advantages of caching if your connection is too slow.

funcs.desc:
Memcache::set() stores an item var with key on the memcached server. Parameter expire is expiration time in seconds. If it's 0, the item never expires (but memcached server doesn't guarantee this item to be stored all the time, it could be deleted from the cache to make place for other items). You can use MEMCACHE_COMPRESSED constant as flag value if you want to use on-the-fly compression (uses zlib).

Remember that resource variables (i.e. file and connection descriptors) cannot be stored in the cache, because they cannot be adequately represented in serialized state. Also you can use memcache_set() function.

return.desc: Returns TRUE on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: var

args.name: flag
args.desc: Use MEMCACHE_COMPRESSED to store the item compressed (uses zlib).

args.desc: Expiration time of the item. If it's equal to zero, the item will never expire. You can also use Unix timestamp or a number of seconds starting from current time, but in the latter case the number of seconds may not exceed 2592000 (30 days).

funcs.name: replace
funcs.desc: Memcache::replace() should be used to replace value of existing item with key. In case if item with such key doesn't exists, Memcache::replace() returns FALSE. For the rest Memcache::replace() behaves similarly to Memcache::set(). Also you can use memcache_replace() function.

return.desc: Returns TRUE on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: key
args.desc: The key that will be associated with the item.

args.name: var
args.desc: The variable to store. Strings and integers are stored as is, other types are stored serialized.

args.name: flag
args.desc: Use MEMCACHE_COMPRESSED to store the item compressed (uses zlib).

funcs.name: get
funcs.desc:
Memcache::get() returns previously stored data if an item with such key exists on the server at this moment.

You can pass array of keys to Memcache::get() to get array of values. The result array will contain only found key-value pairs.

return.desc: Returns the string associated with the key or FALSE on failure or if such key was not found.

args.name: key
args.desc: The key or array of keys to fetch.

args.name: flags
args.desc: If present, flags fetched along with the values will be written to this parameter. These flags are the same as the ones given to for example Memcache::set(). The lowest byte of the int is reserved for pecl/memcache internal usage (e.g. to indicate compression and serialization status).

funcs.name: delete
funcs.desc: Memcache::delete() deletes item with the key. If parameter timeout is specified, the item will expire after timeout seconds. Also you can use memcache_delete() function.

return.desc: Returns TRUE on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: key
args.desc: The key associated with the item to delete.

args.name: expire
args.desc: Execution time of the item. If it's equal to zero, the item will be deleted right away whereas if you set it to 30, the item will be deleted in 30 seconds.

funcs.name: increment
funcs.desc:
Memcache::increment() increments value of an item by the specified value. If item specified by key was not numeric and cannot be converted to a number, it will change its value to value. Memcache::increment() does not create an item if it doesn't already exist.

Do not use Memcache::increment() with items that have been stored compressed because subsequent calls to Memcache::get() will fail. Also you can use memcache_increment() function.

return.desc: Returns new items value on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: key
args.desc: Key of the item to increment.

args.name: offset
args.desc: Increment the item by value.

funcs.name: decrement
funcs.desc:
Memcache::decrement() decrements value of the item by value. Similarly to Memcache::increment(), current value of the item is being converted to numerical and after that value is substracted.

New item's value will not be less than zero.

Do not use Memcache::decrement() with item, which was stored compressed, because consequent call to Memcache::get() will fail. Memcache::decrement() does not create an item if it didn't exist. Also you can use memcache_decrement() function.

return.desc: Returns item's new value on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: key
args.desc: Key of the item do decrement.

args.name: offset
args.desc: Decrement the item by value.

funcs.name: getversion
funcs.desc: Memcache::getVersion() returns a string with server's version number. Also you can use memcache_get_version() function.

return.desc: Returns a string of server version number or FALSE on failure.

funcs.name: flush
funcs.desc: Memcache::flush() immediately invalidates all existing items. Memcache::flush() doesn't actually free any resources, it only marks all the items as expired, so occupied memory will be overwritten by new items. Also you can use memcache_flush() function.

return.desc: Returns TRUE on success or FALSE on failure.

funcs.name: close
funcs.desc: Memcache::close() closes connection to memcached server. This function doesn't close persistent connections, which are closed only during web-server shutdown/restart. Also you can use memcache_close() function.

return.desc: Returns TRUE on success or FALSE on failure.

funcs.name: getserverstatus
funcs.desc:
Memcache::getServerStatus() returns a the servers online/offline status. You can also use memcache_get_server_status() function.

This function has been added to Memcache version 2.1.0.

return.desc: Returns a the servers status. 0 if server is failed, non-zero otherwise

args.name: host
args.desc: Point to the host where memcached is listening for connections.

args.name: port
args.desc: Point to the port where memcached is listening for connections.

funcs.name: setcompressthreshold
funcs.desc:
Memcache::setCompressThreshold() enables automatic compression of large values. You can also use the memcache_set_compress_threshold() function.

This function has been added to Memcache version 2.0.0.

return.desc: Returns TRUE on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: threshold
args.desc: Controls the minimum value length before attempting to compress automatically.

args.name: min_savings
args.desc: Specifies the minimum amount of savings to actually store the value compressed. The supplied value must be between 0 and 1. Default value is 0.2 giving a minimum 20% compression savings.

funcs.name: getstats
funcs.desc: Memcache::getStats() returns an associative array with server's statistics. Array keys correspond to stats parameters and values to parameter's values. Also you can use memcache_get_stats() function.

return.desc: Returns an associative array of server statistics or FALSE on failure.

args.name: type
args.desc: The type of statistics to fetch. Valid values are {reset, malloc, maps, cachedump, slabs, items, sizes}. According to the memcached protocol spec these additional arguments "are subject to change for the convenience of memcache developers".

args.name: slabid
args.desc: Used in conjunction with type set to cachedump to identify the slab to dump from. The cachedump command ties up the server and is strictly to be used for debugging purposes.

args.name: limit
args.desc: Used in conjunction with type set to cachedump to limit the number of entries to dump.

funcs.name: getextendedstats
funcs.desc:
Memcache::getExtendedStats() returns a two-dimensional associative array with server statistics. Array keys correspond to host:port of server and values contain the individual server statistics. A failed server will have its corresponding entry set to FALSE. You can also use the memcache_get_extended_stats() function.

This function has been added to Memcache version 2.0.0.

return.desc: Returns a two-dimensional associative array of server statistics or FALSE on failure.

args.name: type
args.desc: The type of statistics to fetch. Valid values are {reset, malloc, maps, cachedump, slabs, items, sizes}. According to the memcached protocol spec these additional arguments "are subject to change for the convenience of memcache developers".

args.name: slabid
args.desc: Used in conjunction with type set to cachedump to identify the slab to dump from. The cachedump command ties up the server and is strictly to be used for debugging purposes.

args.name: limit
args.desc: Used in conjunction with type set to cachedump to limit the number of entries to dump.

funcs.name: setserverparams
funcs.desc:
Memcache::setServerParams() changes server parameters at runtime. You can also use the memcache_set_server_params() function.

This function has been added to Memcache version 2.1.0.

return.desc: Returns TRUE on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: host
args.desc: Point to the host where memcached is listening for connections.

args.name: port
args.desc: Point to the port where memcached is listening for connections.

args.name: timeout
args.desc: Value in seconds which will be used for connecting to the daemon. Think twice before changing the default value of 1 second - you can lose all the advantages of caching if your connection is too slow.

args.name: retry_interval
args.desc: Controls how often a failed server will be retried, the default value is 15 seconds. Setting this parameter to -1 disables automatic retry. Neither this nor the persistent parameter has any effect when the extension is loaded dynamically via dl().

args.name: status
args.desc: Controls if the server should be flagged as online. Setting this parameter to FALSE and retry_interval to -1 allows a failed server to be kept in the pool so as not to affect the key distribution algoritm. Requests for this server will then failover or fail immediately depending on the memcache.allow_failover setting. Default to TRUE, meaning the server should be considered online.

args.name: failure_callback
args.desc: Allows the user to specify a callback function to run upon encountering an error. The callback is run before failover is attempted. The function takes two parameters, the hostname and port of the failed server.

funcs.name: addserver
funcs.desc:
Memcache::addServer() adds a server to the connection pool. The connection, which was opened using Memcache::addServer() will be automatically closed at the end of script execution, you can also close it manually with Memcache::close(). You can also use the memcache_add_server() function.

When using this method (as opposed to Memcache::connect() and Memcache::pconnect()) the network connection is not established until actually needed. Thus there is no overhead in adding a large number of servers to the pool, even though they might not all be used.

Failover may occur at any stage in any of the methods, as long as other servers are available the request the user won't notice. Any kind of socket or Memcached server level errors (except out-of-memory) may trigger the failover. Normal client errors such as adding an existing key will not trigger a failover.

This function has been added to Memcache version 2.0.0.

return.desc: Returns TRUE on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: host
args.desc: Point to the host where memcached is listening for connections. This parameter may also specify other transports like unix:///path/to/memcached.sock to use UNIX domain sockets, in this case port must also be set to 0.

args.name: port
args.desc: Point to the port where memcached is listening for connections. Set this parameter to 0 when using UNIX domain sockets.

args.name: persistent
args.desc: Controls the use of a persistent connection. Default to TRUE.

args.name: weight
args.desc: Number of buckets to create for this server which in turn control its probability of it being selected. The probability is relative to the total weight of all servers.

args.name: timeout
args.desc: Value in seconds which will be used for connecting to the daemon. Think twice before changing the default value of 1 second - you can lose all the advantages of caching if your connection is too slow.

args.name: retry_interval
args.desc:
Controls how often a failed server will be retried, the default value is 15 seconds. Setting this parameter to -1 disables automatic retry. Neither this nor the persistent parameter has any effect when the extension is loaded dynamically via dl().

Each failed connection struct has its own timeout and before it has expired the struct will be skipped when selecting backends to serve a request. Once expired the connection will be successfully reconnected or marked as failed for another retry_interval seconds. The typical effect is that each web server child will retry the connection about every retry_interval seconds when serving a page.

args.name: status
args.desc: Controls if the server should be flagged as online. Setting this parameter to FALSE and retry_interval to -1 allows a failed server to be kept in the pool so as not to affect the key distribution algorithm. Requests for this server will then failover or fail immediately depending on the memcache.allow_failover setting. Default to TRUE, meaning the server should be considered online.

args.name: failure_callback
args.desc: Allows the user to specify a callback function to run upon encountering an error. The callback is run before failover is attempted. The function takes two parameters, the hostname and port of the failed server.
